review.title: Selective Greedy Equivalence Search: Finding Optimal Bayesian Networks Using a Polynomial Number of Score Evaluations
review.abstract: We introduce Selective Greedy Equivalence Search (SGES), a restricted version of Greedy Equivalence Search (GES). SGES retains the asymptotic correctness of GES but, unlike GES, has polynomial performance guarantees. In particular, we show that when data are sampled independently from a distribution that is perfect with respect to a DAG ${\cal G}$ defined over the observable variables then, in the limit of large data, SGES will identify ${\cal G}$'s equivalence class after a number of score evaluations that is (1) polynomial in the number of nodes and (2) exponential in various complexity measures including maximum-number-of-parents, maximum-clique-size, and a new measure called {\em v-width} that is at least as small as---and potentially much smaller than---the other two. More generally, we show that for any hereditary and equivalence-invariant property $\Pi$ known to hold in ${\cal G}$, we retain the large-sample optimality guarantees of GES even if we ignore any GES deletion operator during the backward phase that results in a state for which $\Pi$ does not hold in the common-descendants subgraph.

sections.text: We are introducing Selective Greedy Equivalence Search (SGES), a limited version of the Greedy Equivalence Search (GES). SGES maintains the asymptotic correctness of GES but, unlike GES, has polynomial performance guarantees. Specifically, we show that when data is collected independently of a distribution that is perfect in relation to a DAG G defined by the observable variables, SGES identifies G's equivalence class in the limitation of large amounts of data according to a number of score ratings that are (1) polynomial in the number of nodes and (2) exponential in different scales of complexity, including the maximum number of parents, the maximum clique size and a new measure called v-width, which is at least as small - and potentially much smaller than - the other two. More generally, we show that for all inheritance and equivalents variants known in G, we do not discard the large sample size of GES once in a given optimum state.

sections.heading: 5 EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: In this section, we present a simple synthetic experiment that compares SBES and BES that demonstrates the value of circumcision operations. In our experiment, we used an oracle scoring function. In particular, our scoring function calculates the minimum description length assuming a data size of five billion records, but without the need to collect data. To estimate the cost of running each algorithm, we counted the number of scoring functions that are required for calculating the expected log losses. This allows us to capture near asymptotic behavior without the need for data.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION
sections.text: Through our selective greedy equivalence search algorithm SGES, we have shown how to use graph-theoretical properties to reduce the need for score graphs during score-based search using equivalence classes of Bayesian networks. In addition, we have shown that for graph-theoretical complexity properties such as maximum clique size, maximum number of parents and V-width, we can guarantee that the number of score ratings is polynomial in the number of nodes and exponential in these complexity measurements. The fact that we can selectively select operators for each hereditary and equivalent invariant graph-theoretical property provides the ability to explore alternative complexity measurements. Another candidate complexity measurement is the maximum number of vstructures. Although the corresponding property does not limit the maximum size of a clique in H, it directly limits the size of H | H for each operator.
